Text.Value: Give me Thrumbo's flesh, and the Torch is yours.

EditorData.NodeContext: Stern, not impressed that you're delayig the handover

Text.Value: Reading two books? Sounds complicated to me.
You possess some aptitude in that regard, but I'm afraid you aren't of the calibre required to be one of my regular clients.
Not so fast. First, tell me about the reward you promised.
I'd like to learn what the spirits know about 'The Necromancy of Thay'. [GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])

EditorData.logicalname: HASN'T SEEN SEANCE, NoT INACTIVE, Haggled

Text.Value: He is bound to me, as I am bound to him. His freedom was never yours to decide.
First you butcher my staff, then you dare to enter my salon without an appointment.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] *DUPE*  Father Carrion is standing in a trance-like state, holding his staff. After a long pause he slams his staff on the ground
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion stands still, almost trance-like at his throne. The player approaches, but he does not seem aware of their presence, then - BANG. He slams his staff on the ground.
EditorData.NodeContext: annoyed, but not overly so. A minor inconvenience

Text.Value: And what do you deserve? You sought the means to help sweet young Oskar, did you not?
Do not think on it too long, lest my offer be rescinded.

EditorData.NodeContext: A bit pissed off - you wasted his time making him explain this. Now treating you like the help, not a customer

Text.Value: Then the Torch of Revocation is yours to use.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The player pays the gold, and in return Mystic Carrion hands them the Torch of Revocation
EditorData.SFXTags: [KP] sound of gold clinking around while being handed over, torch foley

Text.Value: They will follow your progress with great interest. As will I.
I am a spirit medium, one who wanders the hazy boundaries of mortality bearing the intentions of the living, and the knowledge of the dead.

EditorData.NodeContext: Impressing his importance/power on you, but maintaing a sense of mystery

Text.Value: Few possess the temperament required to gaze into death's abyss. Fewer still to reach in and take from it.
I have an assistant, Thrumbo - a conduit I use to maintain my connections with the Ethereal Plane. Unfortunately, he has deserted his duties.
I gave him exactly what he desired, and for a pittance, given the complexity of his request.

EditorData.NodeContext: Recalling his own generosity

Text.Value: Is that so? Yes, I see... A brief and superficial incantation, cast by only the crudest of magicians.

EditorData.NodeContext: At first curious, then snobbish, judging your use of the Speak with Dead spell

Text.Value: Can't I just pay you instead?
I'll just pay the gold. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_4_5dac5eea-faeb-459c-b675-46c51519b784])
They are here.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: A loud BANG. The player looks into the darkness, but sees nothing there. Carrion has not moved.
EditorData.NodeContext: Quieter, addressed to the player (without physically turning to them)

Text.Value: I came to speak to you about your customer Oskar. He's been possessed.
You knew exactly what would happen. You torment him intentionally.
Baldur's Gate is a big city. A name's not much to go on.
You must be very selective. I've never heard anyone mention you.
Hand over Thrumbo's torso.
No more than the ungrateful cur deserved.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The player hands Thrumbo's body to Carrion (unseen).
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion looks down at the corpse that's been thrown at his feet
EditorData.SFXTags: [KP] heavy thud of body as it comes in contact with the ground

Text.Value: Is that so? I hear you already stole something of great value from me. And so, you deserve nothing more.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion tilts his head, as though listening to a voice we cannot hear. His attention returns to the player, unimpressed
EditorData.NodeContext: Pissed off at you, but he got what he wanted so is letting it go. He tilts his head as if listening to a voice we cannot hear, then focuses back on the player

Text.Value: I am a spirit medium, one capable of bridging the void between the living and the unliving, this plane and the next.

EditorData.NodeContext: Correcting you, insulted by your question

Text.Value: Ah. I sense you have trodden the paths of the dead, felt their bones crumble to dust beneath your feet.

EditorData.NodeContext: A flash of recognition - he's figured it out

Text.Value: I'd like to learn what the spirits know about 'The Necromancy of Thay'. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

EditorData.logicalname: HASN'T SEEN SEANCE, NoT INACTIVE, not haggled

Text.Value: Go there. Speak with the proprietor. Perhaps they might sell the key to the book's opening.
An astute observation.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] Carrion stands and slams his staff to unleash a terrifying scream
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The room flickers and whispers around Carrion, as though his spirits are becoming angry. He SLAMS his staff into the ground, unleashing a terrifying scream through the room.
EditorData.SFXTags: [KP] gradually angry wind wafts through, staff slams
EditorData.VFXTags: [KP] room lights flicker (ghosts tampering and angry)

Text.Value: I'm afraid my heart simply isn't in it.
Do you have anything to trade?
Perhaps... can be trusted... perhaps... this one is different...

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] Carrion is channelling, with his head snapped back, and tightly gripping his staff. The staff starts to drift as if moved by an invisible hand, but he still grips it.
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion's staff slides out to the side, as though moved by an unseen hand. He continues to grip it tightly,
EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling. Hissed, as though multiple voices are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: What possible reason could you have to enter the presence of Mystic Carrion?

EditorData.NodeContext: Powerful/compelling -  a hard to resist instruction

Text.Value: I see you were gifted with the courage to stare into death's darkest corners, but not the intelligence to understand it.
'Soulless' is a bold word for an unholy creature like you.
Yes, of course. A Torch of Revocation. Fitting for one so adept at tracking down wayward souls.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion listens, as though receiving an answer from a voice we cannot hear. Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion pauses and listens for a bit, before handing the player a torch

Text.Value: So you choose to leave him a vagrant, destined to be swept from the gutters and discarded?

EditorData.NodeContext: Angry, defensive

Text.Value: A necromancer's secrets are hard won. There's more to this than a simple codex.
And you believe yourself capable of passing such a judgement?
Few exist, and fewer still can be obtained for such a meagre price. It is a rare gift - one some in this city desperately require.

EditorData.NodeContext: Edging towards a threat on the last part of the line

Text.Value: You've got a deal.
Again, you disturb me.

EditorData.NodeContext: Unimpressed

Text.Value: You know what, the Torch of Revocation is plenty.
I assume you came to me seeking an exorcism?
A shame. You could have taken what you needed from them. They are easily controlled.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] *DUPE* Carrion goes from being possessed to relaxing, and back into his original state
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Another BANG and the spirits depart. The atmosphere lifts. Carrion returns to his relaxed pose.

Text.Value: I think it's time to renegotiate. I found the jar hidden in Thrumbo's corpse.
You speak of owning Thrumbo - are you his patron?
I let him go. You'd be wise to do the same.
Some spiritual materials, though not much within reach of your purse, I fear.

EditorData.NodeContext: Casually judgemental

Text.Value: Come now - what's a handful of gold when your life is at stake?
Halls of kings would hold upon my every honeyed word - what do you know of my calibre?
I still want to help Oskar. Tell me about the service you require.
Absolutely not. I won't help you with this.
The Torch will be more than enough to free your little painter friend of his unwanted occupier.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.

Text.Value: Perhaps you will prove more competent once I unshackle your spirit from that useless flesh of yours.
Such a book is for those who make only the shallowest ripples in death's dark pools. I inhabit the depths.

EditorData.NodeContext: amused by your ignorance

Text.Value: And what prize do the spirits wish me to offer? Ah, yes. Take the Torch of Revocation. A generous reward for such a menial service.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion listens, as though receiving an answer from a voice we cannot hear. Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion pauses and listens for a bit, before handing the player a torch

Text.Value: You do not possess the aptitude to attempt such a journey. Nor are you the calibre of client I would usually offer to escort.
His body is chained to that spirit for eternity. I forged the links myself.

EditorData.NodeContext: Malicious, gleeful - knew exactly what would happen

Text.Value: I know. I've heard them screaming for you.
That depends on what torments you. Love. Vengeance. Regret.
Death... destruction... decay... The book must remain sealed.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Two BANGS. Carrion's head snaps back, as though controlled by something else. He's channelling the spirits.
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion's head snaps back. he talks as he's possessed. Hisses, as though multiple voices, different ages and genders, are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through. he seems controlled by something else as he speaks.

Text.Value: Sounds like a waste of gold to me.
Oh yes, I loved it. Especially the part about the unicorns.
But of course. One must never be scared to part with gold - it's better spent than buried.
Leave.
A simple errand seems no price at all for the soul of your artist friend.

EditorData.NodeContext: Feigning confusion - why ever would you refuse?

Text.Value: Don't worry. I'm not here to interfere.
And what do these 'services' involve?
Let us see if it can guide your spirit through the realms of the dead.
Leave.
Is that so? You realise, without me your painter friend hasn't a hope of regaining control of his body.
Those with more... sanguine natures are rarely attuned to the Ethereal Plane, or ready to receive its wisdom -

EditorData.NodeContext: Subtly insulting, dismissing you as unimportant until the spirits interrupt -

Text.Value: Very well. You may help me with a small matter.
The painter. Yes, I remember. He wanted to contact a tormented spirit.

EditorData.NodeContext: with a smile - reminded of a cruel joke he played

Text.Value: Your runaway is already dead, but I can give you this jar I found in his body.
He was always a simple, contented creature - a beggar to the bone. Perhaps he has forgotten how ungenerous the world can be, or simply prefers to live in the gutter.
Take the Torch. Put it to whatever use you see fit.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.

Text.Value: Alas, you do not possess the stomach for such practices. Nor could you afford them if you did.
The spirits provided you with the knowledge required. That is all that matters.
Thrumbo is not alone in his ingratitude - he has led others in my service astray. Three of them - beggars and zombies alike.
In a city like this, reeking with the desperation of the damned, they are not difficult to replace.
It seems that if you want to unlock the mysteries of the Necromancy, you must find the 'Tharchiate Codex'.
If he does not value the gift I gave in reanimating that wretched flesh of his, then I will take it back. It is my property, not his.

EditorData.NodeContext: Callous, indifferent to Thrumbo's death

Text.Value: I came to discuss your client Oskar. He's been possessed.
Had I thought you were the type to shout his name from the rooftops, I never would have offered you the job.
I am more than able to offer you suitable recompense for such a task.
He can decide his own fate, once I've put you back in the grave for good.
Of course, it was hardly my place to speculate on why she chose such a course. Only her spirit could tell you that.

EditorData.NodeContext: Couldn't care less

Text.Value: So if he were richer, you would have protected him?
Oh, no. She has forgotten you entirely.

EditorData.NodeContext: edge of cruelty

Text.Value: She killed herself. Obviously life was too heavy a burden. You'd be surprised how many aren't strong enough to bear it.

EditorData.NodeContext: Couldn't care less about what happpened to her

Text.Value: I came to offer my own services, if you've need of anything.
The living hold such superstition about communing with the dead. As such, my patrons prefer to use my services in the strictest confidence.
I might be able to help. For a fee, of course.
Take time to consider my offer, if that is what you require. I'm sure Oskar has plenty to spare.

EditorData.NodeContext: Subtle manipulation

Text.Value: Thrumbo is a part of me, and I am part of him. He can no more escape me than a fly can escape the spider's web. He is mine. Forever.
What kind of service?
It's quite simple. He requires an exorcism.
I see you fulfilled our agreement, and with admirable gusto.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] Father Carrion with his staff in hand  holds out his other hand as if silencing voices we cannot hear.
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: As the player's approach, Carrion raises a hand, as though silencing voices we cannot hear.

Text.Value: If I could open it, I'd be glad to share an opinion. Unfortunately, it's shut tight.
'Safety' is a concept immaterial to the spectral planes.
Given his condition, I am willing to refund Oskar's original fee. But the Torch of Revocation is what you require to help him.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.

Text.Value: Leave.
So quick to brand another as 'unholy'.
You will not.

EditorData.NodeContext: Menacing, malicious

Text.Value: You do not have an appointment.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] *DUPE* Father Carrion is standing in a trance-like state, holding his staff. After a long pause he slams his staff on the ground
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion stands still, almost trance-like at his throne. The player approaches, but he does not seem aware of their presence, then - BANG. He slams his staff on the ground.
EditorData.NodeContext: Firm, irritated

Text.Value: I met your customer Oskar. He's been possessed.
My name is known to those who matter. So is my discretion.
Unless, of course, you are looking for a job.
It does not matter. The magic at work here does not require your comprehension. Only your participation.
Hand over the gold. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_4_5dac5eea-faeb-459c-b675-46c51519b784])
If a copy of the 'Tharchiate Codex' has entered this city, it will rest on their shelves.
I know you helped Oskar. I found your letter.
And an answer was provided. The dead are not obliged to provide the one you want.
I might seek out their spirit and ask them. As for you - you must seek the Codex.

EditorData.NodeContext: With a smile - amused at the thought of the trial awaiting you

Text.Value: Is that the going rate for canopic jars these days? I expected more.
How can he be freed of the spirit possessing him?
My client list is full. And you are not on it.

EditorData.NodeContext: Dismissive - not looking for an answer back

Text.Value: Lineage alone does not earn you the right to my services. I've turned away bluer blood than yours.
Perhaps you are more like my usual customers than I thought.

EditorData.NodeContext: sneering/dismissive

Text.Value: They have a message for you. A most valuable one. I can summon them forth, if you are willing to offer them suitable recompense. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
I am a Ravengard. My lineage is beyond reproach.
I see Thrumbo's idiocy is contagious.
Foul creature. I will cleanse your stain from this place.
I need time to think about this.
Of course. That's what my clients pay for - to feel safe and superior, even over death itself.

EditorData.NodeContext: unashamed - like it's obvious

Text.Value: Alas, and further education on the subject would cost far more than you are able to pay.
Sealed against those who lack the capability to understand it, no doubt.
Now - hand me his body. Stop wasting time.

EditorData.NodeContext: Getting a little more urgent, annoyed that you're stalling.

Text.Value: Has he? How unfortunate.

EditorData.NodeContext: Knew this would happen, pleased by it

Text.Value: That book tried to kill me. Whatever's inside - it's bad news.
His foolishness did not merit such a cruel punishment.
'Mystic Carrion'? Are you some kind of fortune-teller?
You are a brave soul, to try and manipulate one who makes the dead dance from his fingertips.

EditorData.NodeContext: mildly amused - he doesn't really care about being blackmailed, only about getting the jar back

Text.Value: Your corpse will surrender the jar to me. I will make it.

EditorData.NodeContext: Commanding, angered, as though summoning spirits

Text.Value: My spirits told me you were capable, yet you stand in my presence, and Thrumbo is nowhere to be seen...
Hand over Thrumbo's corpse.
No more than the ungrateful cur deserved.
Hmm. They were... displeased when you refused them. But we may see if they are willing to forgive.
Whatever the customer desires. Or at least, whatever they can afford.
Very well - you may purchase Oskar's salvation. If you can afford it. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_4_5dac5eea-faeb-459c-b675-46c51519b784])

EditorData.NodeContext: A bit pissed off, but still wants to work with you

Text.Value: Ah, I sense you too like to wander the boundaries between life and death. You have read 'The Necromancy of Thay'.
His inability to follow simple instructions is hardly my fault. If he wanted his safety guaranteed, that would have cost him extra.

EditorData.NodeContext: shocked that he might be considered to blame

Text.Value: Have you anything to trade?
You've got a deal.
An item, perhaps. One that resonates with your spiritual energies. The spirits will help me decide, once the task is performed.

EditorData.NodeContext: Considering - hasn't yet made his mind up

Text.Value: What kind of appointments do you offer?
You, for instance, cannot. And so I fear we have nothing left to discuss.
Such a tenacious spirit you possess. I do look forward to meeting it again.
Deny me, spectres, and my ghost will torment you for eternity.
Deny me, spectres, and I will unleash such torments you will beg to die again.
I think it's time you joined them.
Hmmm. Yes, my spirits stir. They think you might be capable.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion raises one hand to his head, as though channeling spirits. A strange wind whistles through the chamber. The light flickers, as though a presence is making itself known.
EditorData.NodeContext: Considering. Carrion, now standing, raises his staff  and puts his other hand on his temple for concentration.

Text.Value: Your corpse will surrender his flesh to me. I will make it.

EditorData.NodeContext: Commanding, angered, as though summoning spirits

Text.Value: Seek it... seek it. SEEK IT.

EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling. Hissed, as though multiple voices are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: Had he followed my instructions, he would never have been harmed.

EditorData.NodeContext: shrugging off the blame

Text.Value: Oskar couldn't afford one tenth of my usual fees. I was indulgent in helping him, but now the spirit must be exorcised.
First, tell me why he ran.
It must be a fine thing when one's moral compass points so unwaveringly towards righteousness.
Some family ties are meant to be broken.
Your purse is deeper than I thought. But wait -

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The player hands Carrion the gold. After taking the gold, Carrion stops, as though listening to somethign the player cannot hear...
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion stops after his line, as if listening to something we cannot hear
EditorData.SFXTags: [KP] sound of gold clinking around while being handed over

Text.Value: Be warned. 'The Necromancy of Thay' is not a book for idle study. I share my spirits' concerns about your aptitude for such knowledge.

EditorData.NodeContext: An idle warning, not really trying to stop you

Text.Value: Ah, yes. You were drawn to me. A wanderer bearing the scent of death. You are familiar with 'The Necromancy of Thay'.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion leans forward, curious.
EditorData.NodeContext: Leans forward, curious

Text.Value: I hear your warning, spirits. The book shall remain unread.
'Tharchiate Codex'... Seek the 'Tharchiate Codex'...

EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling. Hissed, as though multiple voices are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: Is there anything I can do for you?
A simple ask for such a potent prize.

EditorData.NodeContext: As though he knows something/is holding something back.

Text.Value: This message comes from spirits I have collected. Those with great knowledge in life, great wealth, great purpose. It is far more valuable.
A necromantic grimoire of some repute, mostly ill.
Not the hand, but the heart. So sweeten the deal, or I'll destroy the jar.
What else could you require of Mystic Carrion when he has offered so much already?
Who was he trying to contact?
A rash decision - one you will no doubt come to regret.
So you take advantage of the rich and the vulnerable?
Perhaps you'd care for some bindings of your own. I know plenty of spectres who'd kill to possess a body like yours.

EditorData.NodeContext: Commanding, angered, as though summoning spirits

Text.Value: One soul is no great sacrifice to stop someone like you.
I would not form a pact with a creature as base as Thrumbo. He is but a lost tool - one I wish to have returned.
A fair offer, given the boy only has himself to blame.
I don't have his body, but will this jar suffice?
Tell me, what did you make of its contents?
Yes. They know of 'The Necromancy of Thay'. They fear it. They do not want its power released -
The people here required a reassuring hand to navigate such waters, and so I offered mine.
I'd rather just pay the gold. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_4_5dac5eea-faeb-459c-b675-46c51519b784])
We have warned... heed us... never opened... NEVER.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrio's head still snapped back - possession position
EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling, gaining intensity. head still snaped back. Hissed, as though multiple voices, different ages and genders, are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: The others lack even Thrumbo's modicum of intelligence. It should be no great task to wring his location from one of them.

EditorData.NodeContext: Dismissive - couldn't care less what happens to the other three

Text.Value: My spirits will make sure of it.

EditorData.NodeContext: warning, but with a smile (not a prelude to combat)

Text.Value: Leave.
Use it to destroy the painting of his self-destructive lover, and her spirit will be forced to vacate his body.

EditorData.NodeContext: Snappy, businesslike - he wants this conversation to be over

Text.Value: Only a very select few, taken from the highest reaches of society.
Very well. I'll bring you Thrumbo. You agree to free Oskar.
So many souls waiting for you to join them. Wanting to hurt. To harm. To have their revenge.
Three others escaped with him, though they lack even Thrumbo's modicum of intelligence. They can no doubt point you in his direction.

EditorData.NodeContext: To business
EditorData.logicalname: CARRION NOT YET MENTIONED OTHER BEGGARS

Text.Value: I have heard the spirits whisper its name. Few books have the power to send a shiver through the living and the dead.
His 'body'? It sounds like you want him killed.
Now, unless you have any further business with me - I think this consultation has reached its end.
Here's your fee. Tell me how to help Oskar. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_4_5dac5eea-faeb-459c-b675-46c51519b784])
The dead can be put to all sorts of purposes, in the hands of one adept at their manipulation.
So, Thrumbo's filled your head with tales of woe, and yet still he misses the point entirely. Both of you do.
That's what worries me. This seems too easy.
What he seemed to you and what he was to me are two entirely unrelated matters.
I couldn't care less what happens to him. I'm washing my hands of this rotten business.
If that is the sum of your curiosity, then I'm afraid we have nothing more to discuss. In this life, at least.

EditorData.NodeContext: Trying to bring the conversation to a close

Text.Value: Their wrath is one of their finer qualities. A valuable commodity when employed against a mortal enemy, for example.
Feel free to return, so long as you can afford it.
As for why I chose this place as my home - it is a city rife with anguish, rippling with disturbed spiritual energy.
What kinds of clients do you accept?
You ignored my instructions, defied me in favour of that half-wit beggar boy.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] Carrion goes from being possessed to relaxing, and back into his original state
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The spirits depart, whistling as though a terrible wind blows through. Then BANG - they are gone, and the atmosphere lifts. Carrion returns to his relaxed pose.

Text.Value: Idiocy punishes itself. My instructions were clear, as were the consequences of ignoring them.
Unless you have any other business with me, I suggest you return to the domain of the living.
What do you mean? What binds you to him?
I already killed your runaway. Here's his body.
I've had a change of heart. It's your carcass I'm interested in.
It is sufficient to say - you will not be harmed.
What else could you require of Mystic Carrion when he has given so much already?
Hand over the gold. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Had you any concern for Oskar's fate, you'd have helped him already.
He has not gone far, but given the sensitivity of his nature, I would prefer that he is not free to roam the city.
I find them to be far more appreciative of my services than the average mourner. And far more generous in paying for them.
What really happened to Oskar's lover?
Nothing a short-lived creature like yourself would understand.
Elaborate on 'summoning' - is it safe?
That's it? You don't want to punish me for killing everyone upstairs?
Let me guess - my dead grandmother wants to tell me she loves me?
Do as I have asked. Return Thrumbo's body to me, and I will help your painter friend.
A most prescient guest you are. And of course, such an offering must be repaid in kind.
I'd like to trade.
Gratitude is a lesson some never learn. You were wise not to make me teach you.
No... no... leave us be...

EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling, fearful. Hissed, as though multiple voices are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: Terribly sorry but I seem to have, erm, misplaced it.
After that, you can dispatch the spirit as you see fit. It should be well within your capabilities.

EditorData.NodeContext: Doesn't really care what happens

Text.Value: I've decided to keep it. The smell isn't so bad once you get used to it.
Is that so? Then the book's protections must be broken before its true nature can be understood.
So, you choose to deceive me. What you have stolen, I will reclaim. And I will make your soul suffer for it.
Perhaps fate brought us together.
Hush, spirits - I sense it too. Our guest brings with him the stench of Thrumbo's disobedience.
Hush, spirits - I sense it too. Our guest brings with her the stench of Thrumbo's disobedience.
Hush, spirits - I sense it too. Our guest brings with them the stench of Thrumbo's disobedience.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] *DUPE* Father Carrion with his staff in hand  holds out his other hand as if silencing voices we cannot hear.
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: As the player's approach, Carrion raises a hand, as though silencing voices we cannot hear.

Text.Value: A strange offering... yet exactly the one I desired. My spirits did well to whisper my intentions in your ears.

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] *DUPE* Father Carrion with his staff in hand  holds out his other hand as if silencing voices we cannot hear.
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: As the player's approach, Carrion raises a hand, as though silencing voices we cannot hear.

Text.Value: The spirits took some persuading. You're sure their advice can be trusted?
I'd like to hear what the spirits know about 'The Necromancy of Thay'. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
My professional services are available to you, should you be prepared to do something for me. The choice is entirely yours.
Do you have anything to trade?
A simple enough matter to rectify with the Torch of Revocation I gave you.
A naive interpretation of the forces at work beyond your perception. No wonder you sought a hand like mine to lead you through the darkness.
My story has been eternities in the making. Were I to recount it, you would return to dust before I finished the first sentence.
Still, you may find another purpose for the tome. A doorstop, perhaps.

EditorData.NodeContext: Smirking - thinks you're an idiot

Text.Value: You do not have an appointment. Yet you seek an audience with Mystic Carrion...

EditorData.AnimationTags: [MATV] Father Carrion is standing in a trance-like state, holding his staff. After a long pause he slams his staff on the ground
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion stands still, almost trance-like at his throne. The player approaches, but he does not seem aware of their presence, then - BANG. He slams his staff on the ground.

Text.Value: NO... must remain sealed...

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion's staff slides out to the side, as though moved by an unseen hand. He continues to grip it tightly,
EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling. Hissed, as though multiple voices are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: Let it not be said that Mystic Carrion does not take good care of his customers.
What are a few trinkets on the Material Plane when they could let you converse with a beloved mother? Or grant you vengeance where the justice of this world has faltered?
I always have items of interest to those of a curious disposition.
Collaboration is rarely second nature to your kind. But who knows, the writer of this particular tome may have been feeling generous.
You are not deserving of such a gift. Unless you've some other purpose here, our consultation is at an end.
Hmmm... no. Sorry, changed my mind.
Do not worry - it is of an earthly nature. It regards a conduit of mine, Thrumbo, who has recently deserted his duties.
What a plague is the stubbornness of the living. Should you realise your mistake, feel free to return.

EditorData.NodeContext: unsurprised, never thought you were capable

Text.Value: My soft heart is to blame. I was too charitable in offering him my services so cheaply. He was clearly not capable.

EditorData.NodeContext: with a dramatic sigh - woe is me

Text.Value: I'll need to think about it.
How disappointing. I hoped Thrumbo's disobedience would die with him.
It's quite simple: he resented having to work for a living. The undead can be rather lazy in that regard.
Have you anything to trade?
No way. I'm not getting involved.
What's the 'Tharchiate Codex'?
I'd like to hear what the spirits know about 'The Necromancy of Thay'. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
So ready to part with your gold to save yourself the bother of helping someone.

EditorData.NodeContext: Touched a nerve, disrespected

Text.Value: Fear not, spirits. My interests in the book are purely academic.
Strange. My spirits witnessed thieving hands snatching up the very item I wished to give - the Torch of Revocation.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion's focus returns to the player, unimpressed
EditorData.NodeContext: Tilts his head and looks at the player, unphased

Text.Value: The dead divulge their secrets to me readily enough.
Ah - but wait. My spirits stir. Our conversation appears to have... disturbed them.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: A strange wind seems to blow through the chamber. The player looks for the cause, but sees nothing. Carrion puts up a hand ('pause/silence' gesture), tilting his head as though listening to something we cannot hear, then speaks
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion puts up a hand to silence voices, as though hearing someone interrupting (the player hears nothing), and slightly tilts his head

Text.Value: Attack.
Very well. A small discount, as a mark of respect for our mutual expertise. Pay, and I will relay their message. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])

EditorData.NodeContext: amused at your haggling, doesn't really respect you

Text.Value: I gave him safety. I gave him purpose. More than any soul gave him in his mortal lifetime.

EditorData.NodeContext: Angry, defensive

Text.Value: Perhaps the writer of this tome was a particularly generous necromancer. Or perhaps they had other motives for allowing it to be read so easily.
Whatever dangers the book holds, they are only for the living. You will be safe.
This knowledge is mine by right. You must obey.
Leave it be... LEAVE IT BE...

EditorData.NodeContext: Channelling, gaining in intensity and anger. Hissed, as though multiple voices are speaking through him. It cuts in and out, as though only part of the message is coming through

Text.Value: When you have the stomach for the work, you are welcome to return.
It is a Torch of Revocation, a light used only to illuminate the darkest pathways of the damned.
I desired him to be returned to me, and you obliged, thus our terms have been met.
I'm trying to help your customer Oskar. He's been possessed.
Thrumbo seemed harmless enough to me.
The spirits have spoken. 'The Necromancy of Thay' must go unread.

EditorData.NodeContext: suppressing amusement - after all that, the player didn't get what they wanted

Text.Value: Tell me, what brings one of such power into the presence of Mystic Carrion?

EditorData.NodeContext: hint of mockery - the Necromancy of Thay is a children's book, as far as he's concerned

Text.Value: You have not read it.

EditorData.NodeContext: judging, with a smile

Text.Value: You have my thanks for bringing Thrumbo back to me.
You do not get to decide the fates of others. You have earned no such right.
Return Thrumbo's body to me. Then I will give you what you need to cleanse Oskar of his spectral interloper.
I don't need you. I'll find another way to help Oskar.
He is, what do they call them here... ah, a zombie. A waif I rescued from the jaws of death, and gave a second chance at earthly purpose.

EditorData.NodeContext: At first, racking his brain - trying to recall the term to use in this time and place. Then grandiose.

Text.Value: His existence is a mere extension of my own - he lives and dies with me.
You must have some idea of how the book can be opened?
First, you must bring me Thrumbo's body.
You'll do no such thing.
Leave.
My clients are guaranteed absolute privacy in their consultations with myself and my spirits.

EditorData.NodeContext: A point of pride - he would never betray them (slimy)

Text.Value: Is that what we share?

EditorData.NodeContext: amused at your haggling, doesn't really respect you

Text.Value: I am not.

EditorData.NodeContext: Pissed off but in control

Text.Value: I haven't finished it. Somehow I cannot decipher the final pages.

EditorData.logicalname: FINISHED - NOT READ LAST PAGE, NOT READ CYPHER

Text.Value: Those who would breach the bounds of life and death must be willing to defy the doctrines of those on both sides.
Still, such powers are not without danger when wielded by one of your... capabilities.

EditorData.NodeContext: Subtly insulting, 'capabilities' as though he believe you're incapable

Text.Value: Hand over Thrumbo's corpse.
What other services do you provide?
Have we more business in this life? Can it not wait until the next?

EditorData.NodeContext: Slightly bored - "why are you still here?"

Text.Value: Perhaps one day the book will reveal its secrets to you. Until then - they are best left between its covers.
So be it. I have no desire to invoke the wrath of the dead.
Hand over the gold. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Each brings their own desperation. Some crave a word of solace, some wish to see, to summon, to torment - I provide for them all, according to their merit.
Naturally. A few choice items for those seeking contact with the Ethereal planes.
There is a place. 'Sorcerous Sundries'. It is the closest to a necromantic emporium this city has to offer.

EditorData.NodeContext: Slight distaste - it isn't up to his standards

Text.Value: With that, my debt to you is settled. Should you need any further consultations, you will, of course, have to pay for them.

EditorData.NodeContext: Wrapping things up, unapologetic about returning to a mercantile relationship with you

Text.Value: However saccharine your words might be, I assure you they aren't to my tastes.
I hope he is grateful for the price you paid to help him. Generosity like yours should never go unrewarded.

EditorData.NodeContext: Like he knows something you don't (the spirit you exorcise from Oskar will attack you)

Text.Value: Hand his carcass to me. Quickly.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Carrion holds out his hands, expectant
EditorData.NodeContext: Hiding his urgency - he's eager to get back the canopic jar hidden inside. He holds out his hand expectantly

Text.Value: Hand over Thrumbo's torso.
Yes, that will be more than enough. A task most efficiently performed.
If you are unwilling to help me, then I fear we have nothing more to discuss.
You think I would die so easily? You think Thrumbo would live? Fool.
I paid for that consultation. I expected an answer!
I am hardly to blame for the inequalities at play in this city. My price is fair - it is not for I to decide who can afford it.
You'd condemn Oskar to such a fate, all over the words of a soulless ingrate?
You are familiar with 'The Necromancy of Thay'.
Spirits, Mystic Carrion calls on you. Come forth. Listen. Obey.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion raises his staff, putting his other hand to his temple in concentration - he is communing with the spirit realm. The room darkens, the only light a sickly glow over Carrion's form.
EditorData.NodeContext: Carrion, now standing, raises his staff  and puts his other hand on his temple for concentration. Calling out to the room/ghosts. Slightly for the benefit of the player watching him
EditorData.SFXTags: [KP] if possible, could we have silence/stilness here when the room darkens
EditorData.VFXTags: [KP] room darkens start, Carrion's shadow protudes

Text.Value: Clearly these are not waters you know how to swim in. I would hate to be the one who helps you drown.

EditorData.NodeContext: Subtly insulting, 'capabilities' as though he believe you're incapable

Text.Value: As you have paid for your indiscretion, we shall leave the matter at that. Now - get out.

EditorData.NodeContext: A little pissed off, but still feeling he won the exchange with you

Text.Value: I can provide you with the means to perform such a ceremony, but you understand, this is my livelihood. First, you must do something for me.
I'll figure it out for myself.
I'll think about it.
Come now - surely you can offer a better price for one who shares your respect for the dead?
And what do you deserve, I wonder, for meting out such justice?
How did a medium end up in Baldur's Gate?
I can offer a small bonus payment, for services so capably rendered. With this and the Torch, my debt is amply paid.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.

Text.Value: No customer of mine would ever settle for such parlour tricks. Nor would they pay for them.

EditorData.NodeContext: Snobbish, judging your use of the spell

Text.Value: Oh, her death was most ordinary.

EditorData.NodeContext: Couldn't care less about what happpened to her

Text.Value: Return Thrumbo's body to me, and I will see that you are suitably compensated.
A small price for the painter's salvation, I'm sure you'll agree.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Player hands gold over to Carrion. He receives it. (unseen)
EditorData.SFXTags: [KP] sound of gold clinking around while being handed over

Text.Value: My child, that would be asking the impossible. He is already dead.

EditorData.NodeContext: Patronising the player's naivety

Text.Value: So you won't just do it out of the goodness of your heart?
You're familiar with the subject matter?
Then, with the spirits herein our witnesses - the arrangement is made.

EditorData.NodeContext: Formal, sanctifying a pact

Text.Value: I've condemned better people over less.
This is your preferred course - to change the terms of our arrangement now that you feel you have the upper hand?

EditorData.NodeContext: Not impressed, hint of a threat

Text.Value: On second thoughts, tell me what you need.
I give you this Torch of Revocation.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Mystic Carrion hands over the Torch of Revocation. The player accepts.

Synopsis:
Dialog with Mystic Carrion, a mummy lord hiding in the Lower City. Players who carry the Necromancy of Thay (unread) have the chance to take part in a seance where they can learn how the book can be opened. Players can also take on a quest from Carrion, to bring back his runaway zombie beggar Thrumbo (potentially in exchange for the torch of revocation, intended to help Oskar).

Various conclusions are available for the quest to help Mystic Carrion - if the player succeeds in bringing himThrumbo's torso, he will reward them with a Torch of revocation which can be used to cure Oskar's possession (Oskar's Beloved). If you refuse him, he will attack you, and keep returnign from the dead until you destroy his canopic jar (hidden inside Thrumbo)
